abstract: JPMorgan reported a drop in earnings of 50 percent in the first quarter, but beat Wall Street’s expectations.
snippet: JPMorgan reported a drop in earnings of 50 percent in the first quarter, but beat Wall Street’s expectations.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase, fresh from scooping up a rival investment bank, Bear Stearns, saw earnings drop 50 percent in the first quarter as it was hurt badly by market turmoil and heavy credit losses.

headline.main: Reassuring Results From JPMorgan Help Drive Market
headline.print_headline: JPMorgan Income Falls 50% but Beats Forecasts

abstract: Citadel Investment Group has hired away JPMorgan Chase‘s fixed-income chief, Patrik Edsparr, to lead Citadel’s European division, The New York Post reported. The newspaper described the move as the latest sign that Citadel’s founder, Kenneth Griffin, is hoping to compete with big Wall Street firms for business.
lead_paragraph: Citadel Investment Group has hired away JPMorgan Chase‘s fixed-income chief, Patrik Edsparr, to lead Citadel’s European division, The New York Post reported. The newspaper described the move as the latest sign that Citadel’s founder, Kenneth Griffin, is hoping to compete with big Wall Street firms for business.

headline.main: Citadel Said to Hire JPMorgan’s Fixed-Income Chief

abstract: JPMorgan Chase reported first-quarter earnings of $2.4 billion on Wednesday, a nearly 50 percent slump from the same time last year, but still a show of some strength at a time when its rivals have suffered worse.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase reported first-quarter earnings of $2.4 billion on Wednesday, a nearly 50 percent slump from the same time last year, but still a show of some strength at a time when its rivals have suffered worse.

abstract: For all its 85-year history, Bear Stearns is fetching about $1.2 billion in its sale to JPMorgan Chase. Last year alone, at least five hedge-fund managers made more than that.
lead_paragraph: For all its 85-year history, Bear Stearns is fetching about $1.2 billion in its sale to JPMorgan Chase. Last year alone, at least five hedge-fund managers made more than that.
